title: Who will be elected senator from Florida in the 2018 midterm elections?
preds: I think there is a blue wave coming.

Nelson has been ahead in the polls for the majority of this race, and as of Nov. 4th, FiveThirtyEight puts a Scott win at 1/3 probability. It's true that polls can be wrong but, Nelson has been the incumbent since 2001 and has maintained relatively high approval ratings in his tenure. Nelson has seen some lag in approval in recent years but Democrats believe the powerful energy of the Gillum for Governor campaign will help attract more young and black voters to vote democrat (https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/the-senate-spin-cycle/). Florida has also seen a backlash against Trump in part due to the high number of ACA enrolled denizens (https://wellflorida.org/blog/five-years-later-how-aca-is-working-for-florida/). Rick Scott has high approval ratings currently but has been deeply unpopular in the past.  Whichever party comes out on top, the race will likely end within a few points range.

Deviating further toward Nelson winning from 538 model.   There are some quality polls out. Reviewing the polls, I searched for high rated polls that would indicate a Scott win. I found none.  Negative cognitive bias check done. Now I can comfortably call this race for Nelson.  I also looked for polls with the largest pop sample to minimize MoE and found the Trafalgar poll.  https://www.trafalgarstrategy.com/news/fl-govsen-survey-oct-31-2018/   This completes the Narrative of a Nelson win.  Now that I have done many hours of research, I backed my work with a $850 bet for Nelson at  Predict It.  Wish me luck! https://www.predictit.org/markets/detail/2999/Will-Bill-Nelson-be-re-elected-to-the-US-Senate-in-Florida-in-2018
Shifting a few points toward Nelson given his small but persistent lead in polling.
Even up, for now. The Graivis poll has Nelson up by 4 with 6% undecided. It's going to be a squeaker no matter what.

Small lead, but the race has shifted in Nelson’s favor.
https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2018/senate/fl/florida_senate_scott_vs_nelson-6246.html

Some of the same things that benefit Gillum also apply to this race. Nelson should receive more of the advantages of incumbency in a Democrat-friendly environment. I also think that Gillum is driving more turnout among groups less traditionally likely to vote, and that will spillover into the Senate race.  Florida is still a swing state, and people that split their ticket in 2016 might not like Republican control of the executive and legislative branches and will vote that intention here.
I believe turnout will favor Democrats here with Gillum for Governor that will help Nelson.
Was following the wrong Bill nelson’s Twitter feed.
Note to self: Calling it now  0.650 2018 < 0.696 2014  ~5%blue wave offset in deep red country.
I know something you don't know.

So going off book here to my Best Friend - who has just opened a General Contractors office in the panhandle - it'll come down to turn out in the panhandle and how well or poorly the recovery from the Hurricane goes and how it is spun.

I am basing this conclusion off of the polling performed by Nate Silver's FiveThirtyEight statistical analysis website, which shows incumbent Nelson (D) leading with a 3 in 5 chance of winning the election in November (https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2018-midterm-election-forecast/senate/florida/).
Shifting toward Nelson due to potential effects of Hurricane Michael on turnout in the Panhandle as noted by @ttltran.

revise down the chance for Scott due to Michael. Scott didn't do anything bad with regard to handling Michael, and generally such thing helps the sitting governor. However, the bastion of republican voters in Florida (the Panhandle has been consistently republican) is hard-hit by the hurricane and voting is not on their mind right now.
Shifting a little toward Nelson because he has pulled away from Scott a bit in polling (and I like the idea that Gillum pulls him over the finish line by activating young voters).
538 says D=60  I adjusted +2% to Dems due to Hurricane pounding predominant Rep territory in Panhandle  thereby lowering likely voter status in coming weeks. Territory effect was discussed on BBC.

I think this will be a very close senate race. However, I am predicting Rick Scott will narrowly win against Bill Nelson. Currently, Rick Scott is outspending his opponent 4 to 1 (Vox). In addition, Nelson is a strong centrist, but many are predicting he will move further left in this campaign, ultimately dissuading his centrist voters (USA Today). Moreover, Nelson has a very laid-back persona, which does not lend its self well to campaigning - especially in the Trump era of politics. As a result, it is possible he may not get the necessary votes.  https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/elections/2018/09/03/florida-senate-race-rick-scott-bill-nelson-face-off-epic-matchup/1067783002/
https://www.vox.com/policy-and-politics/2018/4/6/17181110/rick-scott-bill-nelson-florida-senate-2018-midterm-elections
https://www.politico.com/story/2018/08/27/bill-nelson-florida-senate-democrats-rick-scott-795695

I don't understand how Scott is in his 2nd term as Governor. He is a poor communicator and comes from a shady business background. On the other hand Nelson looks like he is dialing it in and that he has reached his sell by date. May the worst man lose! This will be a  nail biter.
The polls show this to be a tossup, notwithstanding 538 giving Nelson a more substantial lead. Scott is still pretty popular in large swaths of Florid. I think Nelson has a very slight edge.
Bill has weathered many storms.   He's not controversial and his opponent barely got elected governor without all the flack that President Trump has thrown out in front of him

538 deluxe model forecast. The deluxe model includes not only 538's analysis, but factors in ratings from other experts like the Cook Political Report. An average of all the experts should give the most accurate forecast.
Shifting just a few points toward Nelson based on today's polling.

Incumbents are more likely to be reelected than ousted. Rick Scott had low approval rating for the last several years making him an unlikely candidate in the first place. Large student pop in Florida more likely to vote blue based on historical precedent. Trump has also seen depreciating approval rates in FL. High multi-gen immigrant pop., likely backlash to DACA/zero tolerance immigration policy/child separation.
Based on Scott's lack of popularity as a govenor and the environmental issues along with the gun violence that Florida has faced.
Nelson has done a wonderful job as senator.   Scott has done a poor job as governor

Too many reasons to list.. but here is a good one... 
In the battleground state of Florida, 
Republicans outvoted democrats by 139,220 votes this week. The 2016 United States presidential election in Florida was won by Donald Trump on November 8, 2016, with a plurality of 49.0% of the popular vote that included a 1.2% winning margin over Hillary Clinton, who had 47.8% of the vote. Popular vote: 4,617,886 @3x the margin of 2016... and a lot less vote in midterms (historically). So, do the math.
https://www.tampabay.com/florida-politics/buzz/2018/08/28/primary-voter-turnout-nears-2-million-will-easily-break-2014-total/ R's by >5% Just a taste of what to look forward to this November.

The gubernatorial primary in Florida last Tuesday removes one tool from this predictor's toolbox: the freaking polls!
The poll before primary day predicted Graham win by some 5 points. Yet Gillum won decisively. And deSantis supposedly wins by a plurality but actually won decisively.  I am looking for a sign that disprove my theory: that while Trump supporters remain loyal and will come out to vote, the more mainstream GOPs realize Trump is not as bad as they feared, so they will come out to defend his presidency, knowing losing Congress would put an end to the 4% gdp growth we are seeing. I have not seen that theory invalidated, certainly not in Florida yesterday.. While I can't underestimate Gillum, after all he came from nowhere to first, I don't think the winning strategy for Democrats to go socialist, especially in better economic time. Yet, Dems keep on parading out from New York to Georgia, and now Florida, leftist candidates. But who am I to give advice. An unpaid advice worths it's cost.
Update: last few polls all have Scott ahead by an average of 4%. Crowd: 49/51

Danger signs for Republicans.   Primary turnout by noon has already beat 2014 totals.   Looks to be a record turnout, in some districts topping 25%.    As of noon, in orange county, republican and democrat vote totals were *identical*.  That said .. Bill Nelson is a kind gentleman, and a nice guy.  But his age is showing. https://www.floridaturnout.com/   Republican had a 50K advantage in early voting.

Nelson is going to have a strong finish. However - that means pumping the voters 24/7 for about 3 weeks prior to the election, and if this fatigues or exhausts him , or he is muddled in his thinking and answers to query's - it'll show. (The Whisper Mill is circulating claims that he isn't understated - but sedated.) Will that sell? IDK.
50-49-1 now 50-50. Scotto has lotsa moula and buying lotsa ads.  But this Blue Wave is so real.
Any other outcome spells doom for America
Trailing in the polls when you're an incumbent in what should be a good year for your party is a really bad sign.
Because of Scott’s popularly and his ability to spend his own money.
As far as swing states are concerned, this one seems more difficult: https://www.vox.com/policy-and-politics/2018/7/30/17614554/2018-midterms-state-legislature-elections-gerrymandering
With all the folks moving from Puerto Rico if dems get them to vote in mass Scott is dead!
Adjusting a little based on prediction market odds: https://www.predictit.org/Contract/5564/Will-Bill-Nelson-be-re-elected-to-the-US-Senate-in-Florida-in-2018#data
The wave of conservatism rules Florida.

Six of the 49 U.S. Senate seats currently held by Democrats are potentially at risk in the midterm elections.* Five of these six seats are in states that Donald Trump won by double digits. The sixth is in the perennial swing state of Florida.
i THINK nelsons STANCE ON PROHIBITING PUBLICATION OF 3dPRINTING DESIGNS IS GOING TO THROW THE DECISION TO Scott.

Scott has a lead in polling but Generic ballot shows a Dem bias of +9.2. But, I think Scott might be a better candidate a not fit the typical mold as a Republican...possibly seen as more centrist. I give a Slight edge to Nelson https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/what-some-early-high-quality-polls-can-tell-us-about-the-race-for-the-house/

Mr. Scott must openly oppose many of president Trumps policies in order to appease Florida's voters.  A significant sentiment and support for president Trump comes from people who live in Florida but vote in their main domicile in other states.  Also, a significant chunk of Republicans in general will have grown sick of all politics and either break from the pack or not vote.  Mr. Scott, always a sort of unpredictable entity, will try to draw in moderate and conservative dems, who will want some way to stick it to the party which fumbled the past two years so badly by rejecting a generic, career legislator, Mr. Nelson, and vote for Mr. Scott whom, upon closer scrutiny, proposes a basically center of the road agenda. https://rickscottforflorida.com/make-washington-work/.  Low turnout, but Mr. Scott will likely win a plurality of Florida voters in 2018.
Real Clear polling average gives Rick Scott with 45.2 pts, Bill Nelson with 44.4.  Too close and still too early to tell. Giving Nelson the edge for now.

New Puerto Ricans, if they're on the rolls and turnout might favour D.  Depends on economy and how much Trumpy chaos affects Florida. Tourism industries may see a decrease, especially if weather goes extreme mode.  If fmr Gov Scotto blows enough smoke up Trumpos orange cottage cheese derriere then it could get the nipped and tucked Trumpette crowd to dig in to their Birken and Chanels to buy lots of attack ads. But Scotto could shoot his own foot or score an own goal with some funny craziness.
Scott was governor and Nelson is incumbent. They both have statewide name recognition. While the race is tight at this moment, Scott has momentum.
These two seem more of less tied but Scott has nearly unlimited money in an expensive state.

Two very well known candidates means both have attracted enough votes in the past to win elections.  Since both campaigns will be well funded that should not give an advantage to either candidate. This will be very close and the outcome may well depend on last minute events in the economy and foreign affairs.

The latest poll has Nelson up by 4 points, 10% undecided. An incumbent with that kind of deficit is probably in trouble. I assume Scott will not make a jackass out of himself during the campaign, so he will likely get most of that 10% on election day.
The relocation of disenfranchised Puerto Ricans and the families of those still there might be enough to keep Nelson in place.
World is moving in a Blue direction; Scott may take a hit, but it will be close.
